sub_fields.title: Describe what makes your idea innovative compared to what has been previously launched in the market (whether by you or others).
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
Most “DeSci” projects on any chain today do one of three things:



	•	Tokenise funding (grants, bounties, NFTs),

	•	Store scientific files on IPFS/Filecoin with basic hashes, or

	•	Run governance / communication for researchers.



_ChimiaDAO tackles a different layer entirely: the data model of chemistry itself\._



Key innovations:



**	1\.	Type‑safe chemical model, not just strings**



	•	Instead of raw SMILES/SELFIES, we model molecules and reactions as Haskell algebraic data types with explicit atoms, bonds, charges and stoichiometry.

	•	This lets us enforce invariants (mass/charge balance, atom conservation, required fields) both off‑chain and in Plutus validators. No existing on‑chain chemistry project does this.



**	2\.	Cardano‑anchored validation of reaction steps**



	•	We don’t just store “a paper hash” or a PDF.

	•	Each reaction step becomes a CIP‑68 token + datum that is structurally validated by Plutus. Cardano acts as the canonical truth and reputation layer for individual experiments.



**	3\.	Deep integration with the Open Reaction Database \(ORD\)**



	•	We already parse ORD protobufs and extract reaction classes, conditions and molecules.

	•	The prototype focuses on mapping real ORD reactions into our ADTs and onto Cardano, not inventing toy examples.



**	4\.	Minimal, purposeful multi‑chain design**



	•	Monad (high‑throughput EVM) is used for fast experiment submission and challenge games.

	•	Filecoin keeps raw data (spectra, logs) permanently.

	•	Cardano remains the arbiter: every valid experiment ends up as a Cardano UTxO that points to those external artefacts.



	**5\.	Incentive layer tuned to scientific behaviour**



	•	Experiments carry stakes and reputation scores; challenges reward those who catch bad data.

	•	Reputation is type‑aware (e.g., HPLC, NMR, PXRD) rather than a single undifferentiated number.

	6.	Re‑usable infra, not a single app

	•	The chimia-core library and CIP‑68 schemas are designed so other teams can build explorers, analytics, DeFi around scientific IP, or even entirely different scientific domains on top.



Instead of “NFTs for science” or “generic data hashes”, ChimiaDAO will use Cardano to build a formal, programmable representation of chemistry with on‑chain validation and incentives.

sub_fields.title: Describe what your prototype or MVP will demonstrate, and where it can be accessed.
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
The MVP will demonstrate an end‑to‑end path from a real chemical reaction to a Cardano UTxO plus linked off‑chain evidence:



**	1\.	Haskell library \+ CLI**



	•	Users can take a reaction from ORD (or their lab notebook), run it through our CLI, and see:

	•	Structural validation (mass/charge/atom balance),

	•	A generated CIP‑68 datum, and

	•	A ready‑to‑submit transaction payload.



**	2\.	Cardano pre‑prod deployment**



	•	Plutus validators live on Cardano pre‑prod.

	•	The prototype will show at least 50 ORD reactions and ≥1 full multi‑step retrosynthesis path encoded as validated UTxOs.

	•	Anyone can query the policy ID and inspect the datums.



**	3\.	Monad \+ Filecoin testnet pilot**



	•	A user can register an experiment on Monad testnet with a stake and references to Filecoin CIDs.

	•	A relayer then writes the relevant hashes and CIDs into a Cardano reaction‑step datum.

	•	Challenge flows (with multi‑sig resolution) can be exercised.



**	4\.	Web UI \(“Chimia Portal”\)**



	•	Connect a Cardano wallet (e.g. Lace or Nami).

	•	Select or upload a reaction, preview the derived datum, and submit a transaction to pre‑prod.

	•	View validation status, linked Monad/Filecoin information, and reputation.



**	5\.	Public accessibility**



	•	Code: GitHub under Apache‑2.0, including chimia-core, Plutus scripts, Monad and Filecoin contracts.

	•	Live pre‑prod contracts: documented addresses and example tx IDs.

	•	Demo UI: hosted at a public URL, linked from the repo and proposal.



Anyone in the community will be able to:



	•	Clone the repo,

	•	Reproduce the example reactions, and

	•	See the resulting Cardano UTxOs in a pre‑prod explorer.

sub_fields.title: Describe realistic measures of success, ideally with on-chain metrics.
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
**On‑chain / technical metrics**



	•	≥50 ORD reactions from ≥3 reaction classes successfully encoded and validated on Cardano pre‑prod.

	•	≥1 multi‑step (≥5 steps) retrosynthesis pathway represented as a chain of reaction‑step UTxOs.

	•	≥200 reaction‑step UTxOs under the project’s policy ID on pre‑prod.

	•	≥25 unique Cardano wallets interacting with the demo UI or CLI to submit reactions.

	•	Validator performance: document script size, CPU and memory budgets, and target acceptable fees (e.g. under a few ADA per transaction on mainnet).



**Cross‑chain metrics**



	•	≥50 experiments registered on Monad testnet with stakes and corresponding Filecoin/IPFS CIDs.

	•	≥1,000 ORD reactions uploaded as a pilot subset to Filecoin via our tooling (not all 4M+, just a representative sample).

	•	At least 5 challenge flows executed end‑to‑end on testnet.



**Adoption / community metrics**



	•	≥5 labs or scientific groups participating in the pilot (feedback calls, test usage).

	•	≥100 experiments (historic or new) submitted via UI or CLI.

	•	≥5 GitHub stars and ≥5 external contributors (code, docs or data).

	•	At least 1 preprint / talk / blog post referencing ChimiaDAO’s Cardano architecture.



Hitting these numbers would show that:



	•	The data model is expressive enough for real chemistry,

	•	The Cardano contracts are usable and affordable, and that there is genuine interest from early adopters.

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
The root problems are:

```
•	Chemistry data locked in proprietary formats,

•	Slow, centralised verification, and

•	No incentive to share well‑structured experimental results (and most importantly, "failed" experiments).
```
Our solution attacks all three:

```
1.	Open, type‑safe data model for chemistry



•	We define molecules and reactions as Haskell ADTs with explicit atoms, bonds and charges.

•	We provide parsers from ORD/SMILES to these types and invariant checks (mass/charge balance, atom conservation).

•	This makes the data machine‑checkable and portable across labs and tools.



2.	Cardano as a verifiable registry of reaction steps



•	Each reaction step becomes a CIP‑68 token with a datum that encodes the typed reaction plus pointers to raw data (e.g. spectra on Filecoin).

•	Plutus validators enforce structural correctness and CIP‑68 layout, giving an on‑chain guarantee that any reaction registered under the policy ID at least meets baseline scientific sanity checks.



3.	Multi‑chain infra for speed and storage



•	Monad handles high‑throughput experiment submission and a stake‑based challenge game.

•	Filecoin/IPFS store large experimental artefacts and a pilot subset of ORD reactions.

•	A relayer writes the relevant CIDs and hashes into Cardano datums, keeping Cardano as the final arbiter.

4.	Incentives and reputation

•	Experiments include stakes that can be lost if successfully challenged.

•	Researchers build reputation scores tied to experiment types (e.g. strong track record in NMR‑heavy workflows).

•	Over time this gives labs a direct incentive to publish clean, well‑structured data instead of hiding it.
```
By the end of the project, any lab will be able to:

```
•	Take a reaction they run,

•	Validate it via our library,

•	Anchor it as a verifiable reaction step on Cardano, and

•	ptionally plug into a multi‑chain incentive layer.
```
This turns chemistry from siloed PDFs into programmable, composable on‑chain infrastructure.

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
For the Cardano ecosystem, the project delivers impact at several levels:

	1.	New DeSci / RWA vertical

	•	Cardano gains a credible, technically interesting flagship in decentralised science focused on chemistry.

	•	It showcases Cardano’s strengths (Haskell, eUTxO, CIP‑68) in a field that matters far beyond crypto.

	2.	Reusable on‑chain standards

	•	The chimia-core library and CIP‑68 schema for reaction steps can be reused by:

	•	explorers,

	•	analytics platforms,

	•	IP marketplaces, or

	•	other DeSci projects (drug discovery, materials, climate chemistry).

	3.	Developer opportunities

	•	Indexers and DeFi protocols can build on top of reaction‑step tokens (e.g. derivative contracts on reproducible synthesis, funding instruments for labs).

	•	Smart contract developers get a non‑financial, data‑rich testbed for advanced Plutus patterns.

	4.	Attracting scientists and institutions

	•	By integrating real ORD data and piloting with labs, Cardano becomes visible in scientific circles that currently gravitate to Ethereum and generic IPFS tools.

	•	This can lead to future collaborations, grants, and academic work centred on Cardano.

	5.	Educational and outreach value

	•	The open‑source repo, demos and documentation can be used in university courses or workshops on blockchain + scientific reproducibility.

	•	It provides a clear, tangible example of “why a UTxO ledger matters” outside DeFi.

	6.	Long‑term potential

	•	Once the primitive exists, further work (ZK proofs, privacy‑preserving experiments, DAO‑funded lab work) can build on it, multiplying the value of this initial investment.

sub_fields.title: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.description: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.answer:
Capability

	•	The team has already shipped a working prototype for ETHGlobal SF 2024 that won a Polygon “Best Consumer App” runner‑up prize, including contracts, a subgraph, and a demo UI.

	•	We have working Python scripts parsing real ORD protobufs into structured reaction data.

	•	Initial Haskell modules for molecules, atoms and orbitals are already integrated in the repo.

	•	We are used to hackathon deadlines and public demos – output is visible and auditable.



Trust and accountability

	•	All code will be open‑sourced under Apache‑2.0 and developed in public GitHub branches.

	•	We will use CI for tests and keep a clear CHANGELOG and tagged releases (v0.1, v0.2, v1.0).

	•	Each milestone has explicit acceptance criteria (e.g. number of reactions, UTxOs, wallets) that the community can verify from the chain and repo.



Feasibility validation

	•	We deliberately start with a restricted subset of reactions and ORD data rather than “all chemistry”. This keeps complexity manageable and provides fast feedback.

	•	Early milestones (M1, M2) are Cardano‑only: library + validator + testnet anchoring. If these fail, we won’t pour effort into cross‑chain integration.

	•	We will engage a handful of labs early for pilot feedback; if they cannot use the tools we course‑correct before over‑engineering.



In short: we have already proven we can build and ship, and the plan is structured so each milestone de‑risks the next.

sub_fields.title: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.description: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.answer:
Depth vs. breadth: For ₳200k, the ecosystem gets:

	•	a reusable Haskell chemistry library,

	•	audited Plutus validators and CIP‑68 schemas,

	•	working testnet deployments, and

	•	a demo UI and pilot labs.

This is closer to a research+infra grant than a simple app build.

	•	Multiplicative effect:

	•	Once reaction‑step tokens exist, many other teams can build explorers, analytics, funding mechanisms, insurance, and DeFi products on top without reinventing the core data model.

	•	The same infra can later be extended to other fields (materials, battery chemistry, catalysis, etc.).

	•	Attracting non‑crypto capital:

	•	If successful, this work can be cited in grant proposals, research programmes and industrial collaborations that bring new funding and users into Cardano.

	•	Benchmark for multi‑chain DeSci:

	•	The project also acts as a reference architecture for how Cardano can sit at the centre of multi‑chain scientific workflows (fast EVM chains + storage networks) while retaining governance and truth.
